conclusion: Determine the magnitude and direction of the current in the rod when the tension in the wires is one-fourth of the tension when the rod is not energized.
A thin copper rod MN is horizontally suspended in a uniform magnetic field directed into the paper.
When the rod is not energized, the only force acting on the rod is its weight mg, and the tension in each wire is mg/2.
The magnetic force on the rod when energized is given by FB = BIL, acting horizontally.
The tension in each wire is reduced to 1/4 of the original tension when energized.
The tension in each wire when energized is T = mg/8.
Balance the vertical forces: 2T + FB = mg.
Substitute T and rearrange to find FB: BIL = 3mg/4.
Solve for the current I: I = 3mg/4BL.
Determine the direction of the current using the right-hand rule: current flows from M to N.
Final answer: Magnitude of the current is I = 3mg/4BL, direction is from M to N.
